question.context: A command and control behavior was blocked on host `vnevado-win10r`, which indicated an active infection by malware that could replicate and receive commands from remote attackers. This malware was active, and precautionary measures should be taken to check for residual signs of infection. The process involved had the ID 1332 and ran the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`.
question.question: What is the IP address associated with the Manatee Tempest activity group detected in this security incident?
solution: The account with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` was involved in a Command and Control behavior that was blocked.
The cybercriminal group known as Manatee Tempest, which is associated with the IP address `198.43.121.209`, was active during the incident.

question.context: A Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on a device at 2024-07-04 22:35:03.797541+00:00. Mimikatz is a tool used to harvest plaintext passwords, password hashes, smartcard PINs, and Kerberos tickets. The attacker might be leveraging this tool to harvest credentials to log into this or other devices on the network by impersonating a valid user. Several command line executions involving `mimikatz.exe` were observed, along with connected mimikatz-related files like `mimidrv.sys`, `mimispool.dll`, and `mimilove.exe`. More information can be found in the Mimikatz tool profile Threat Analytics report and the Actor profile: Storm-0875 Threat Analytics report provided by Microsoft.
question.question: Can you identify the IP address involved in the malicious credential theft tool execution detected?
solution: The Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on the device with IP address `107.224.99.179`.
A malicious credential theft tool execution was detected on the same device with IP address `107.224.99.179`.

Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]

•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]

[('e34d562e-ef12-4c4e-9bc0-7c6ae357c015', '2024-06-20 09:19:23.604535+00:00', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

question.context: A ransomware payload was remotely launched on a host named `vnevado-win11t` with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`. Attackers might be attempting to encrypt content on this device, rendering it unusable to users. For more information, refer to the Threat Analytics report, Threat overview: Human-operated ransomware: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/05658b6c-dc62-496d-ad3c-c6a795a33c27/analystreport. Soon after, potentially compromised assets began exhibiting ransomware-like behavior, impacting multiple devices.
question.question: What is the name of the file associated with the ransomware-like behavior identified in the potentially compromised assets?
solution: A ransomware payload was remotely launched by the user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
Potentially compromised assets are exhibiting ransomware-like behavior involving the file `syncretic.7z.lockbit`.

[('All file snapshots and shadow copies have been deleted via WMI or VSSAdmin which is common during Ransomware infection.

For more information, read the Activity Profile: Iranian MOIS operators opportunistically deploy limited-impact wiper in response to Israel-Hamas war Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/c6674205-df28-453a-9e42-0010b7979bdd/overview?tid4b2462a4-bbee-495a-a0e1-f23ae524cc9c', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:15:11","IncidentId":"324","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"There is no one-size-fits-all response if you have been victimized by ransomware. There is no guarantee that handing over the ransom will give you access to your files again. Paying the ransom could also make you a target for more malware.

•	Contact your incident response team.
NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic investigation. A forensic investigation is important to identify Indicators of Compromise (IoC) that may be used to prevent other machines from installing the malware.
•	Check if files on the affected machine were encrypted by ransomware.
        o	If files were encrypted, disconnect the machine from the network as soon as possible.
•	Check for other suspicious events in the machine timeline.
•	Check for the observed deleted file name or SHA1 on other machines in the network.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email)
•	Rebuild the affected machine.
•	After the affected machine has been rebuilt: 
         o	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
         o	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
         o	Configure your Trust Center to disable macros.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"ca3d4939-c0fe-4a2f-8ebd-48a0ac00e0aa","MitreTechniques":"T1490","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('All file snapshots and shadow copies have been deleted via WMI or VSSAdmin which is common during Ransomware infection.

•	After the affected machine has been rebuilt: 
         o	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
         o	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
         o	Configure your Trust Center to disable macros.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"ca3d4939-c0fe-4a2f-8ebd-48a0ac00e0aa","MitreTechniques":"T1490","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}'), ('The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

question.context: There was a detection of unknown malware being active in the environment, which was stopped by Windows Defender but it is recommended to further check the machine for signs of infection. Following that, there were multiple alerts indicating possible attempts to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) which is a key artifact used for Azure AD authentication. Additionally, we observed an alert where system recovery settings were tampered with, indicating that adversaries might be attempting to delete or disable built-in operating system data and recovery services. This could prevent recovery of a corrupted system and denie access to backups and recovery options. Various built-in Windows utilities can be exploited to disable or delete system recovery features, posing a risk to system integrity.
question.question: What is the name of the account involved in the system recovery setting tampering incident?
solution: An unknown malware was detected and was active on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) involving the process `browsercore.exe`.
The user with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` was involved in a potential attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT).
System recovery setting tampering was observed on the account named `dp5hn`.

[('e34d562e-ef12-4c4e-9bc0-7c6ae357c015', '2024-06-20 09:19:23.499691+00:00', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]', 'MDATP', 'Microsoft', '5984c937-d71d-4fb9-9eb9-e0eddb531b1c_1', '65e0e94f-36d8-f3a7-039e-c1770857c3ce', '', '', 'WindowsDefenderAtp', '', '', 'False', '2024-06-20 09:10:48.076628+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:10:50.905677+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:19:23.178094+00:00', '["1. Make sure the machine is completely updated and all your software has the latest patch.","2. Contact your incident response team. NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic.","3. Install and run Microsoft’s Malicious Software Removal Tool (see https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/malicious-software-removal-tool-details.aspx).","4. Run Microsoft’s Autoruns utility and try to identify unknown applications that are configured to run at login (see https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb963902.aspx).","5. Run Process Explorer and try to identify unknown running processes (see https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb896653.aspx)."]', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:15:11","IncidentId":"324","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"•	Contact your incident response team. Perform a forensic investigation and assess the impact of successful breach activities. If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.  
•	Check if files on the affected device were encrypted by ransomware. If files were encrypted, isolate the affected devices.
•	Check the device timeline for other suspicious activities.
•	Check other devices on the network for the observed deleted file name, or SHA1.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email).
•	Rebuild the affected device. 
•	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
•	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
•	Deploy the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) utility for behavioral-based exploit prevention.
•	Configure your Trust Center to disable tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]', 'MDATP', 'Microsoft', '3fcede41-9fdb-4dfb-9fd0-69f1c6fa88bf_1', '8edf196f-fae8-6f94-3acd-93c648e9aa1f', '', '', 'WindowsDefenderAtp', '', '', 'False', '2024-06-20 09:29:38.767268+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:29:41.284899+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:39:59.777330+00:00', '["1. Make sure the machine is completely updated and all your software has the latest patch.","2. Contact your incident response team. NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic.","3. Install and run Microsoft’s Malicious Software Removal Tool (see https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/malicious-software-removal-tool-details.aspx).","4. Run Microsoft’s Autoruns utility and try to identify unknown applications that are configured to run at login (see https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb963902.aspx).","5. Run Process Explorer and try to identify unknown running processes (see https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb896653.aspx)."]', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:38:35","IncidentId":"107","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":"Defender Experts","Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"•	Contact your incident response team. Perform a forensic investigation and assess the impact of successful breach activities. If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.  
•	Check if files on the affected device were encrypted by ransomware. If files were encrypted, isolate the affected devices.
•	Check the device timeline for other suspicious activities.
•	Check other devices on the network for the observed deleted file name, or SHA1.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email).
•	Rebuild the affected device. 
•	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
•	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
•	Deploy the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) utility for behavioral-based exploit prevention.
•	Configure your Trust Center to disable tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]', 'MDATP', 'Microsoft', '3e6bd315-8c89-4a24-8579-9601035ef416_1', '62857e21-c95b-4124-457c-3bdcef05583f', '', '', 'WindowsDefenderAtp', '', '', 'False', '2024-06-20 09:32:00.329557+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:32:03.749465+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:44:53.379230+00:00', '["1. Make sure the machine is completely updated and all your software has the latest patch.","2. Contact your incident response team. NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic.","3. Install and run Microsoft’s Malicious Software Removal Tool (see https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/malicious-software-removal-tool-details.aspx).","4. Run Microsoft’s Autoruns utility and try to identify unknown applications that are configured to run at login (see https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb963902.aspx).","5. Run Process Explorer and try to identify unknown running processes (see https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/bb896653.aspx)."]', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:38:35","IncidentId":"107","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":"Defender Experts","Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"•	Contact your incident response team. Perform a forensic investigation and assess the impact of successful breach activities. If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.  
•	Check if files on the affected device were encrypted by ransomware. If files were encrypted, isolate the affected devices.
•	Check the device timeline for other suspicious activities.
•	Check other devices on the network for the observed deleted file name, or SHA1.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email).
•	Rebuild the affected device. 
•	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
•	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
•	Deploy the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) utility for behavioral-based exploit prevention.
•	Configure your Trust Center to disable tampering', 'System recovery setting tampering', 'High', 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]', 'MDATP', 'Microsoft', '7d47542a-7c5a-4fd4-85f2-640f2bf0927b_1', '37ed1840-2428-9ace-8db4-fc7ceeda30b9', '', '', 'WindowsDefenderAtp', '', '', 'False', '2024-06-20 09:10:49.054537+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:10:51.876113+00:00', '2024-06-20 09:44:53.384727+00:00', '["1. question.context: A security incident involving the Manatee Tempest activity group was flagged, where the actor Manatee Tempest, known for its early malware campaigns like the Dridex banking trojan, has been active since June 2014. The group utilizes tactics such as drive-by downloads and FakeUpdates infections, facilitated by Mustard Tempest to gain initial access. Later, they use the BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. One of the events related to this incident involved a process running on the host `vnevado-win11t` using the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`. The Process ID was 88.
question.question: There was another instance of a similar process being run on the same host in this incident. Can you identify the Process ID and the command line of this process?
solution: A user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96` was associated with suspicious activity linked to the Manatee Tempest cybercriminal group.

A process with Process ID `1332` used the command line `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com` on `2024-06-20t09:10:52.7298237z`, indicating possible interaction with a malicious domain associated with Manatee Tempest.

question.context: A security incident involving multiple alerts reported by various entities. One of the alerts indicates the detection of active unknown malware that poses a significant threat as it can perform harmful actions and has persistence mechanisms in place.
question.question: What was the URL associated with the command and control behavior that was blocked?
solution: Active unknown malware was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
Lateral movement to the jump server was conducted using PSExec to IP address `99.83.111.100`.
Potentially compromised assets with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` exhibited ransomware-like behavior, impacting several devices.
A malicious command and control behavior directed to the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/` was blocked.

[('Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Some of these undesirable applications can replicate and spread from one machine to another. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

A malware is considered active if it is found running on the machine or it already has persistence mechanisms in place. Active malware detections are assigned higher severity ratings.

Because this malware was active, take precautionary measures and check for residual signs of infection.', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Malware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":"24","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"PendingApproval","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:06:34","IncidentId":"321","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAv","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. 1. Find related machines, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.
2. Check for other suspicious activities in the machine timeline.
3. Locate unfamiliar processes in the process tree. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
4. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors. 
5. Identify unusual system activity with system owners. 

B. If you have validated the alert, contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Record relevant artifacts, including those you need in mitigation rules.
2. Stop suspicious processes. Block prevalent malware files across the network.
3. Isolate affected machines.
4. Identify potentially compromised accounts. If necessary, reset passwords and decommission accounts.
5. Block relevant emails, websites, and IP addresses. Remove attack emails from mailboxes.
6. Update antimalware signatures and run full scans. 
7. Deploy the latest security updates for Windows, web browsers, and other applications.

C. ('Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

This detection might indicate that Windows Defender has stopped the malware from delivering its payload. ('The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

('The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:15:11","IncidentId":"324","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. ('Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Some of these undesirable applications can replicate and spread from one machine to another. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

A malware is considered active if it is found running on the machine or it already has persistence mechanisms in place. Active malware detections are assigned higher severity ratings.

Because this malware was active, take precautionary measures and check for residual signs of infection.', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Malware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":"24","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"PendingApproval","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:16:10","IncidentId":"321","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAv","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. 5. Identify unusual system activity with system owners. 

B. If you have validated the alert, contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Record relevant artifacts, including those you need in mitigation rules.
2. Stop suspicious processes. Block prevalent malware files across the network.
3. Isolate affected machines.
4. Identify potentially compromised accounts. If necessary, reset passwords and decommission accounts.
5. Block relevant emails, websites, and IP addresses. Remove attack emails from mailboxes.
6. Update antimalware signatures and run full scans. 
7. Deploy the latest security updates for Windows, web browsers, and other applications.

C. ('Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Some of these undesirable applications can replicate and spread from one machine to another. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

A malware is considered active if it is found running on the machine or it already has persistence mechanisms in place. Active malware detections are assigned higher severity ratings.

Because this malware was active, take precautionary measures and check for residual signs of infection.', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Malware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":"24","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"PendingApproval","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:16:10","IncidentId":"321","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAv","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. 1. Find related machines, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.
2. Check for other suspicious activities in the machine timeline.
3. Locate unfamiliar processes in the process tree. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
4. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors. 
5. Identify unusual system activity with system owners. 

B. If you have validated the alert, contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Record relevant artifacts, including those you need in mitigation rules.
2. Stop suspicious processes. Block prevalent malware files across the network.
3. Isolate affected machines.
4. Identify potentially compromised accounts. If necessary, reset passwords and decommission accounts.
5. Block relevant emails, websites, and IP addresses. Remove attack emails from mailboxes.
6. Update antimalware signatures and run full scans. 
7. Deploy the latest security updates for Windows, web browsers, and other applications.

C. ('The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

The process id `1332` was observed running the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com` on this host with AadDeviceId `9d4887ba-0b69-47d6-89bc-9b32787f379e`. question.context: A security incident involved a possible compromised user account delivering ransomware-related files across multiple devices. Among these, ransomware-related files named `ponceau.7z`, `unstreaming.xlsx.lockbit`, `syncretic.7z.lockbit`, and others were observed on the device with host name `vnevado-win11u`. The device also had its unique Azure Active Directory ID `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`. Shortly after this, suspicious remote activity was detected. This type of activity might include attempts to initiate sessions, modify files, and more.
question.question: What is the host name of the machine where suspicious 'GenRansom' behavior was detected, indicating the machine is actively running malware?
solution: A user account from IP address `99.83.111.100` was observed delivering ransomware-related files on several devices.
Suspicious remote activity was initiated on the host `vnevado-win11t`.
Suspicious 'GenRansom' behavior was detected on the host `vnevado-win11t`.

question.context: To further investigate the incident, 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the targeted device. An attacker might be attempting to move laterally from another device on the network.
question.question: Can you identify the AadUserId of the account related to the CommandAndControl malware that was detected during lateral movement?
solution: Active malware was detected running or with persistence mechanisms on the machine associated with account `tgs2z` on `2024-07-04`.
Lateral movement detected using PSExec to the jump server at IP address `99.83.111.100` on `2024-07-10`.
Potential compromise and ransomware-like behavior detected on host with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033` on `2024-07-04`.
Command and control malware detected during lateral movement involving user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96` on `2024-07-04`.

question.context: The Manatee Tempest activity tracked by Microsoft is a notorious Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014, and involved in various malicious activities such as drive-by downloads and ransomware deployment. A recent incident associated with this group involved a suspicious HTTP request to `vectorsandarrows.com` from the IP address `198.43.121.209` using the command line: `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`, with process ID 6460. Additionally, system recovery setting tampering with the command `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` was observed, likely to hinder recovery options in case of system corruption.
question.question: What is the process ID and the exact time when the `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` command was executed as part of the system recovery setting tampering?
solution: The account `dp5hn` is associated with activity from the Manatee Tempest cybercriminal group known for using tactics such as drive-by downloads, malvertising, and FakeUpdates to gain initial access.

A system recovery setting tampering attempt was detected with the command `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` executed by process ID `8136` on `2024-06-20t09:10:48.0438707z`, which might indicate an attempt to disable system recovery features on the device.

question.context: On July 4, 2024, at 22:35:01, a security incident involving system recovery setting tampering was observed. The device `vnevado-win11t` with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033` was targeted. Command lines `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all` and `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` were executed, which may indicate that adversaries attempted to stop or delete system recovery features to prevent recovering a corrupted system.

solution: The user account `dp5hn` was observed tampering with system recovery settings, possibly attempting to delete or disable recovery features.

Suspicious remote activity was detected from IP address `99.83.111.100`, which could indicate attempts to initiate interactive sessions, modify files, pass WMI commands, create scheduled tasks, or other malicious activities.

question.context: A possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected on the host `vnevado-win11u` with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`. The process involved in this attempt was `browsercore.exe` (ProcessId: 1640), launched at `2024-06-20T09:32:12.1031042Z`. PRT is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication used for single sign-on across applications, and attackers may target it to move laterally or perform credential theft. For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report on the Microsoft Security website.

question.context: During an investigation of a security incident, it was observed that 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the host `vnevado-win10r`, which might be an indication of an attacker attempting to move laterally from another network device. The process was initiated via the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com` with Process ID 1332. The incident is part of a larger campaign by the Manatee Tempest activity group, which is known for various cyber-attacks including the use of Cobalt Strike beacons for lateral movement and ransomware deployment.
question.question: As part of the Manatee Tempest activity group, what is the IP address associated with their activity in this incident?
solution: The 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on a device. An attacker might be attempting to move laterally to this device from another device on the network. The associated user account has the SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.

Manatee Tempest, a Russia-based cybercriminal group active since June 2014, was identified. This group was responsible for the Dridex banking trojan and various other malvertising and infection methods. They have been observed partnering with Mustard Tempest to facilitate initial access. They use the IP address `198.43.121.209` for their activities.

question.context: An active unknown malware was detected, which assigned higher severity ratings due to its active state and potential persistence mechanisms. This malware was running on an unspecified host and included processes involving mimikatz.exe and cmd.exe, indicating credential theft activities. Following this malware detection, a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was identified, signifying that attackers could be trying to acquire this Azure AD authentication artifact to perform lateral movements or credential theft.
question.question: Can you identify the AadUserId associated with the possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT)?
solution: Active malware was detected on the host `vnevado-win10v`.
There was a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) using the process `browsercore.exe`.
The account with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96` was associated with a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT).

question.context: A security incident involving multiple malicious activities was detected. It started with a known credential theft tool, `mimikatz.exe`, being executed at two different times, indicating an attempt to dump users' credentials. This activity led to lateral movement attempts to the jump server and suspicious remote activities on the machine. Subsequent analysis revealed command and control behavior of malware which was blocked.
question.question: What was the URL associated with the command and control behavior detected in the end alert?
solution: A known credential theft tool execution was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
There was lateral movement to the jump server from the IP address `99.83.111.100` using PSExec.
Suspicious remote activity was observed on the account `dp5hn`.
Command and Control behavior was blocked for the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/`.

[('Command and Control behavior was blocked', 'Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Some of these undesirable applications can replicate and spread from one machine to another. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

A malware is considered active if it is found running on the machine or it already has persistence mechanisms in place. Active malware detections are assigned higher severity ratings.

Because this malware was active, take precautionary measures and check for residual signs of infection.', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"CommandAndControl","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:12:57","IncidentId":"323","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAv","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. Validate the alert and scope the suspected breach.
1. Find related machines, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.
2. Check for other suspicious activities in the machine timeline.
3. Locate unfamiliar processes in the process tree. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
4. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors. 
5. Identify unusual system activity with system owners. 

B. If you have validated the alert, contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Record relevant artifacts, including those you need in mitigation rules.
2. Stop suspicious processes. Block prevalent malware files across the network.
3. Isolate affected machines.
4. Identify potentially compromised accounts. If necessary, reset passwords and decommission accounts.
5. Block relevant emails, websites, and IP addresses. Remove attack emails from mailboxes.
6. Update antimalware signatures and run full scans. 
7. Deploy the latest security updates for Windows, web browsers, and other applications.

C. ('Command and Control behavior was blocked', 'Malware and unwanted software are undesirable applications that perform annoying, disruptive, or harmful actions on affected machines. Some of these undesirable applications can replicate and spread from one machine to another. Others are able to receive commands from remote attackers and perform activities associated with cyber attacks.

A malware is considered active if it is found running on the machine or it already has persistence mechanisms in place. Active malware detections are assigned higher severity ratings.

question.context: A potential security incident involving a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected. A file `browsercore.exe` was launched on the host `vnevado-win11t` by an account with the name `dp5hn` and SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`. The process ID for this event was `7036`. This activity may have been an attempt by attackers to access the PRT to move laterally within the organization or perform credential theft. The Primary Refresh Token is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on various platforms and is essential for single sign-on (SSO) across applications.
question.question: Can you identify the AadDeviceId related to this alert?
solution: A possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected on the host with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`.

question.context: During a recent security investigation, it was found that a malicious credential theft tool `mimikatz.exe` was executed with the process ID 4464 on 2024-06-20 at 09:03:04.6442161, originating from IP address `107.224.99.179`. The command line included attempts to leverage credentials from the domain `vnevado.alpineskihouse.co`. This execution was flagged on 2024-07-04 at 22:35:03.869406+00:00 for its intent to dump user credentials. Subsequently, there was a lateral movement attempt to the jump server `Vnevado-jump` on 2024-07-10 at 11:24:45.260113+00:00.
question.question: During this investigation, a potentially compromised user account was identified. Can you provide the SID of the user account that may be operating with ransomware-like behavior?
solution: A known credential theft tool execution command was detected on the account with the name `tgs2z`.
Lateral movement to the jump server `Vnevado-jump` was performed from the IP address `99.83.111.100`.
The account with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` was exhibiting ransomware-like behavior, impacting several devices.

question.context: A security incident involving an attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected. The PRT is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on various devices, including Windows 10. The incident involved a device with HostName `vnevado-win10s` and AadDeviceId `f5b847aa-8712-4bf6-b4f7-ed6cd89e1505`, where the process `browsercore.exe` (ProcessId `2676` created at `2024-06-20T09:10:59.867384Z`) was running. Attackers may use this to move laterally within the organization.
question.question: Following this incident, 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on another device during lateral movement. What is the AadDeviceId of this affected device?
solution: A possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected for the user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the device with AadDeviceId `bc00e484-d0e5-4da4-9472-95568cccc07e`, indicating an attempt of lateral movement.

question.context: A security incident involving the Manatee Tempest activity group was reported. This Russia-based cybercriminal group, which has been active since June 2014, is known for malware campaigns including the Dridex banking trojan. They often gain initial access through methods such as drive-by downloads and malvertising, facilitated by their partnership with Mustard Tempest. As part of this security incident, a suspicious WMI process creation was observed on the machine `vnevado-win10r`, which might be an indicator of malware using WMI to spawn new processes and further infect the machine.

question.context: A recent security incident involved the modification of the LSASS process memory. This process enforces security policy by verifying user logons and password changes. Attackers might modify LSASS memory to bypass security mechanisms or circumvent legitimate checks. In the same incident, the device `vnevado-win10v` showed signs of the Mimikatz hacktool being detected.
question.question: What is the name of the credential theft tool detected on the device `vnevado-win10v`?
solution: The LSASS process memory was modified on host `vnevado-win10v`.
The Mimikatz credential theft tool, known as mimikatz.exe, was detected on the same host `vnevado-win10v`.

question.context: A security incident involving suspected tampering with system recovery settings using various commands and processes, including `vssblatemp.exe` to delete all volume shadow copies, was observed on device `vnevado-win11t` (AAD Device ID: `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`). During the incident, the process `vssblatemp.exe` was executed with command: `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all`. This is part of an adversarial attempt to prevent the recovery of corrupted systems by deleting built-in operating system data or turning off recovery services. The incident was detected on 2024-07-04. This tampering could deny access to available backups and recovery options, augmenting the effects of data destruction or data encryption.
question.question: Can you identify the executable file name of the process that attempted to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) as part of the related alerts?
solution: There was system recovery setting tampering by the Azure AD user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) involving the process `browsercore.exe`.

question.context: A Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on a device. Mimikatz is a credential theft tool that can harvest plaintext passwords, password hashes, smartcard PINs, and Kerberos tickets. Attackers may use this tool to harvest credentials to log into this or other devices on the network by impersonating a valid user. The detection of Mimikatz is part of a broader security investigation. Additionally, there was later evidence of lateral movement to the jump server `Vnevado-jump` using PSExec.
question.question: A related alert indicated a possible compromised user account dropping ransomware-related files. Can you identify the name of the specific file associated with the ransomware activity?
solution: The Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on the device with AadDeviceId `4d8d23e9-a77d-4e33-9435-b8c457e57ca1`.
Lateral movement to the jump server occurred using PSExec to IP address `99.83.111.100`.
A compromised user account was observed dropping a ransomware-related file named `get-userprttoken.ps1` on several devices.

question.context: A security incident involving suspicious 'GenRansom' behavior was detected on the host `vnevado-win11t` with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`. Malware activity was found, necessitating precautionary measures. Additionally, there was an alert about system recovery setting tampering, where adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system.
question.question: During this incident, what specific command line was observed that could indicate system recovery setting tampering on the device?
solution: There was suspicious 'GenRansom' behavior detected on the device with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`.
Lateral movement using SMB remote file access was blocked for the user with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522`.
System recovery setting tampering was observed with the process having ProcessId `4312`, created at `2024-06-20t09:10:48.0676225z`, and the command line `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no`.

These commands were executed around the same time frame, raising concerns about potential malicious activities.

For more information, read the Activity Profile: Iranian MOIS operators opportunistically deploy limited-impact wiper in response to Israel-Hamas war Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/c6674205-df28-453a-9e42-0010b7979bdd/overview?tid4b2462a4-bbee-495a-a0e1-f23ae524cc9c', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:15:11","IncidentId":"324","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"There is no one-size-fits-all response if you have been victimized by ransomware. There is no guarantee that handing over the ransom will give you access to your files again. Paying the ransom could also make you a target for more malware.

•	Contact your incident response team.
NOTE: If you don’t have an incident response team, contact Microsoft Support for architectural remediation and forensic investigation. A forensic investigation is important to identify Indicators of Compromise (IoC) that may be used to prevent other machines from installing the malware.
•	Check if files on the affected machine were encrypted by ransomware.
        o	If files were encrypted, disconnect the machine from the network as soon as possible.
•	Check for other suspicious events in the machine timeline.
•	Check for the observed deleted file name or SHA1 on other machines in the network.
•	Find the infection source and block it (IP or email)
•	Rebuild the affected machine.
•	After the affected machine has been rebuilt: 
         o	Ensure your software has the latest patch, update your malware signatures, and close the vectors of attack.
         o	Move out-of-date applications to other systems to reduce the attack surface.
         o	Configure your Trust Center to disable ('Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":null,"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":"UnsupportedAlertType","LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:13:33","IncidentId":"324","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":null,"Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A.  Validate the alert.  
1.  Check for other suspicious activities in the device timeline.  
2. Locate unfamiliar processes in the process tree. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.  
3. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors.  
4. Identify unusual system activity with system owners.  
 
B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.   
 
C. Contain and mitigate the breach. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected devices, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.  
 
D. Contact your incident response team or contact Microsoft support for forensic analysis and remediation services.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"3dbe5ef6-24e8-4eac-bc8e-5682665b4d90","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}', ('Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

('Possible compromised user account delivering ransomware-related files', 'A user account was observed dropping a ransomware-related file on several devices. An attacker may have compromised the said user account to move laterally across the network and infect as many devices with ransomware as possible. Automated remediation action may be taken to disable the account.', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":"27","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":null,"LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:38:52","IncidentId":"107","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":"Defender Experts","Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. Validate the alert.
1. Check if the device owner or IT personnel had a legitimate reason to launch the command.
2. Look for recent signs of activity by the compromised user account and investigate them. Make sure to check other devices in your organization, as well as the original device associated with the compromised account.
3. Review device timelines for suspicious activity that may have occurred around the time of the alert.
4. Look for unfamiliar processes. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
5. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors.
6. Look for the presence of relevant artifacts on other devices. Identify commonalities and differences between potentially compromised devices.

B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.

C. Contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected systems, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.
2. If you believe that you have a false positive, and a user has been suspended automatically, re-enable them via the MDI portal or Active Directory.

D. ('Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

('Potentially compromised assets exhibiting ransomware-like behavior', 'Potentially compromised assets are exhibiting ransomware-like behavior, impacting several devices. An attacker may be operating using the specified user account, IP, or device to move laterally across the network and infect as many devices as possible with ransomware. Automated remediation action might be taken to disable the account or device the attacker used.', '{"MicrosoftDefenderAtp.Category":"Ransomware","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationId":"26","MicrosoftDefenderAtp.InvestigationState":null,"LastUpdated":"06/20/2024 09:38:52","IncidentId":"107","DetectionSource":"WindowsDefenderAtp","AssignedTo":"Defender Experts","Determination":null,"Classification":null,"Action":"A. Validate the alert.
1. Check if the device owner or IT personnel had a legitimate reason to launch the command.
2. Look for recent signs of activity by the compromised user account or device and investigate them. Make sure to check other devices in your organization, as well as the original device associated with the compromised assets.
3. Review device timelines for suspicious activity that may have occurred around the time of the alert.
4. Look for unfamiliar processes. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures.
5. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors.
6. Look for the presence of relevant artifacts on other devices. Identify commonalities and differences between potentially compromised devices.

B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph.

C. Contain and mitigate the breach.
1. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected systems, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.
2. If you believe that the alert is a false positive:
     2.1 A user may have been suspended automatically. Revert the action by enabling the user account through the MDI portal or Active Directory.
     2.2 Devices may have been automatically contained. Revert the action through the device page in the portal.

D. Contact your incident response team or contact Microsoft support for investigation and remediation services.","ThreatName":null,"ThreatFamilyName":null,"DetectorId":"a438e864-e77a-43d1-8858-520e652f7c3d","MitreTechniques":"T1486","ProcessedBySentinel":"True","Alert generation status":"Full alert created"}', '[{"$id":"2","Name":"dp5hn","NTDomain":"vnevado.alpineskihouse.co","Sid":"S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522","AadUserId":"731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96","IsDomainJoined":true,"DisplayName":"Grace Chen","Asset":true,"Type":"account","UserPrincipalName":"dp5hn@vnevado.alpineskihouse.co"},{"$id":"3","Address":"99.83.111.100","Type":"ip"},{"$id":"4","ProcessId":"4","ElevationToken":"Default","CreationTimeUtc":"2024-06-13T07:28:17.8849024Z","ImageFile":{"$id":"5","Directory":"C:\Windows\System32","Name":"ntoskrnl.exe","FileHashes":[{"$id":"6","Algorithm":"SHA1","Value":"7fe78f91310839df0993510df2bccab4a51618fa","Type":"filehash"},{"$id":"7","Algorithm":"MD5","Value":"bb4c983627632ef38b8c1bbe4a5650ee","Type":"filehash"},{"$id":"8","Algorithm":"SHA256","Value":"d2c63f71382ab464c9b243e4f19f123fb4b44917468ddb6928a57f90fe94664a","Type":"filehash"}],"CreatedTimeUtc":"2024-06-12T14:12:01.9269267Z","Type":"file"},"CreatedTimeUtc":"2024-06-13T07:28:17.8849024Z","Type":"process"},{"$ref":"5"},{"$ref":"6"},{"$ref":"7"},{"$ref":"8"},{"$id":"9","Directory":"\Device\HarddiskVolume4\Users\4qs6v9m\OneDrive - 2. Check for similar activity on other devices within the same network to identify possible ongoing infection.
3. Check for other suspicious activities in the device timeline. Identify unusual system activity with system owners. ​
4. Look for the presence of relevant artifacts on other systems. Identify commonalities and differences between potentially compromised systems.
5. Submit relevant files for deep analysis and review file behaviors.

B. Scope the incident. Find related devices, network addresses, and files in the incident graph. Check files for prevalence, their locations, and digital signatures. ​

C. Contain and mitigate the breach. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected devices, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.

question.context: A security incident involving a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected. The file `browsercore.exe` was launched with the command line `browsercore.exe` on process ID 1640 at 2024-06-20T09:32:12.1031042Z. The PRT is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication used to enable single sign-on (SSO) across devices. Attackers might attempt to access this token to move laterally within the organization or perform credential theft. For more information, check the Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report.

question.context: A security incident was detected involving 'CommandAndControl' malware which attempted lateral movement on the host `vnevado-win10s` with AadDeviceId `f5b847aa-8712-4bf6-b4f7-ed6cd89e1505`. Additionally, a process with ProcessId `6460` was observed running the command `curl http://vectorsandarrows.com`. Further investigation revealed another process with ProcessId 4828 that was executed.
question.question: On the same host `vnevado-win10s`, there was a tampering activity observed. Can you identify the command that was executed to disable the automatic Windows recovery features?
solution: The 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on a device associated with the account `dp5hn`.
System recovery settings were tampered with using the `bcdedit` command line `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` at `2024-06-20T09:31:59.6743318Z`, with Process ID `4828`.

question.context: A serious security incident involving the Mimikatz credential theft tool was detected on a device. Mimikatz is known for harvesting plaintext passwords, password hashes, smartcard PINs, and Kerberos tickets. An attacker might use this tool to obtain credentials to log into this or other devices on the network by impersonating a valid user. The tool was executed with several different command lines indicating privilege escalation and credential theft attempts.
question.question: What was the command line of the process detected with the known credential theft tool execution?
solution: The attacker launched `mimikatz.exe` with the command line `privilege::debug sekurlsa::pth /user:fk8mq /ntlm:96def1a633fc6790124d5f8fe21cc72b /domain:vnevado.alpineskihouse.co /run:..\notepad.exe \vnevado-jump cmd.exe` at `2024-06-20t09:05:15.5627318z`, with Process ID `6600`.
A malicious credential theft tool execution was detected with the command line `conhost.exe 0xffffffff -forcev1` at `2024-06-20t08:59:42.8455252z`, with Process ID `7948`.

solution: Manatee Tempest, a Russia-based cybercriminal group, was involved in the use of access broker Mustard Tempest to facilitate infections and lateral movement using BLISTER loader and Cobalt Strike beacons on various networks. The group used domain fronting for command-and-control of Cobalt Strike.
A suspicious account with SID `S-1-5-21-1840191660-8534830288-125585561-1522` was identified in the context of the Manatee Tempest group activities.
The 'CommandAndControl' malware was detected on the host `vnevado-win10s`, indicating an attempt at lateral movement within the network.

question.context: An incident occurred involving the potential compromise of devices showing ransomware-like behavior. An IP address associated with this is `99.83.111.100`, and files such as `get-userprttoken.ps1`, `characterical.zip`, and `characterical.zip.lockbit` were detected. Additionally, there was an incident of system recovery setting tampering. The tampering might involve adversaries deleting or removing system data and turning off recovery features to prevent system restoration.
question.question: Can you identify the process command used that might have tampered with the system recovery settings?
solution: The device with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033` is potentially compromised and exhibiting ransomware-like behavior.

On 2024-06-20 at 09:29:40.8785892 UTC, the process vssblatemp.exe with Process ID `1900` was executed with the command line `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all` to tamper with system recovery settings by deleting volume shadow copies.

question.context: A security incident started with lateral movement detected from IP address `83.162.58.168`. The alert was flagged as 'Possible lateral movement' and indicated that an attacker might be trying to gather data or elevate privileges by moving across different devices. This alert was based on a Microsoft Defender for Endpoint alert. Shortly after, at 2024-07-04 22:35:03.652724+00:00, a 'Command and Control behavior' alert was triggered due to malware activities. This malware was active and necessitated precautionary measures. Finally, an alert flagged as 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)' was observed, indicating an attempt to access Azure AD authentication resources which could facilitate lateral movement or credential theft.
question.question: What is the hostname of the device where a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected?
solution: There was possible lateral movement observed on another device associated with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`.
Command and control behavior related to malware was blocked, and the associated account name is `dp5hn`.
A possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected on the host `vnevado-win10s`.

[('e34d562e-ef12-4c4e-9bc0-7c6ae357c015', '2024-06-20 09:00:03.183652+00:00', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

C. Contain and mitigate the breach. Stop suspicious processes, isolate affected devices, decommission compromised accounts or reset passwords, block IP addresses and URLs, and install security updates.

attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT)', 'Medium', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

question.context: A security incident was detected involving a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT), which is an important artifact for Azure AD authentication. This event was associated with the process `browsercore.exe` running on the host `vnevado-win11t` with the AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`. PRTs enable Single Sign-On (SSO) and, if compromised, can allow an attacker to move laterally or perform credential theft.
question.question: In this incident, potentially compromised assets are exhibiting ransomware-like behavior. Can you identify the name of the file that has been impacted by ransomware?
solution: There was a possible attempt to access a Primary Refresh Token (PRT) by the user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
Potentially compromised assets exhibiting ransomware-like behavior were detected, involving a file named `unstreaming.xlsx.lockbit`.

question.context: A security incident related to the Manatee Tempest activity group was also identified. Manatee Tempest is known for using various methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (SocGholish) infections, to obtain initial access, and they frequently use BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The group also employs domain fronting for command-and-control channels.
question.question: Can you identify the malicious IP address associated with the Manatee Tempest group activities?
solution: All file snapshots and shadow copies on the account `dp5hn` were deleted which is common during a ransomware infection.
The cybercriminal group, Manatee Tempest, known for deploying ransomware and other malware, accessed using IP address `198.43.121.209`.

[('Manatee Tempest activity group', 'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport', question.context: As part of the process leading to the discovery of an unknown malware, we found that components such as `cmd.exe`, `mimikatz.exe`, and `notepad.exe` were executed to conduct unwanted malicious activities. While the investigation revealed that an alert was raised due to the detection of this malware, the machine should still be thoroughly examined to rule out any possible infection.
question.question: Relating to this incident, a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected. Can you identify the file name of the process involved in this attempt?
solution: An unknown malware was detected with the IP address `107.224.99.179` and was active.
There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) via the process `browsercore.exe`.

question.context: A security incident related to the Manatee Tempest activity group has been detected. This actor, tracked by Microsoft and known to be a Russia-based cybercriminal group, has been active since June 2014 and is notorious for its Dridex banking trojan campaigns. The group partners with Mustard Tempest to facilitate access to target networks via methods such as drive-by downloads, malvertising, and FakeUpdates infections. They use a BLISTER loader to deploy Cobalt Strike beacons for lateral movement and ransomware deployment.
