question.context: A suspicious WMI process creation was observed on the machine. Malware frequently uses WMI to spawn new processes, breaking process trees and further infecting a machine. This activity occurred at 2024-07-04 22:35:03.378778+00:00. During the same incident, there was a possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) detected. A PRT is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication and is a JSON Web Token (JWT) issued to enable single sign-on (SSO) across applications used on devices such as Windows 10 and later versions, iOS, and Android. Attackers might attempt to access this token to move laterally or perform credential theft.
question.question: The answer points to browsercore.exe running at the specified time. This should be further scrutinized to confirm the activity related to PRT access attempt mentioned.
solution: There was a suspicious WMI process creation detected on the machine with AadDeviceId `e5799261-6720-4297-961e-bd9ca4275033`.
There was a possible attempt to access the Primary Refresh Token (PRT) through the process `browsercore.exe`, which was executed with Process ID `7036` at `2024-06-20t09:29:49.304018z`.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]'), ('vnevado-win11t.vnevado.alpineskihouse.co', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

'The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

For more information, read the Actor Profile: Manatee Tempest Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/a22c3410-db8f-4c58-866e-ebb760e509d0/analystreport'), 'System recovery setting tampering has been observed on this device. Adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.

Operating systems may contain features that can help fix corrupted systems, such as a backup catalog, volume shadow copies, and automatic repair features. Adversaries may stop or delete system recovery features to augment the effects of Data Destruction and Data Encrypted for Impact.

Many native Windows utilities have been used by adversaries to disable or delete system recovery features:
•	 vssblatemp.exe can be used to delete all volume shadow copies on a system using the following command: [vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all /quiet]
•	Windows Management Instrumentation can be used to delete volume shadow copies using the following command: [wmic shadowcopy delete]
•	wbblatemp.exe can be used to delete the Windows Backup Catalog using the following command: [wbblatemp.exe delete catalog -quiet]
•	bcdedit.exe can be used to disable automatic Windows recovery features by modifying boot configuration data using the following command: [bcdedit.exe /set default bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set default recoveryenabled no]'), ('vnevado-win11t.vnevado.alpineskihouse.co', "Possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) has been detected. A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Azure AD authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016 and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. It is a JSON Web Token (JWT) that's specially issued to Microsoft first party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into organization or perform credential theft.

For more information, read the Activity profile: Midnight Blizzard credential attacks Threat Analytics report: https://security.microsoft.com/threatanalytics3/e4aad043-a273-4f88-b65e-fdfc3996ec92/analystreport?

question.context: As part of a Ransomware infection observed in our organization, file backups were deleted via WMI or VSSAdmin on the host `vnevado-win10r`. The process involved was identified with ProcessId__CreatedTimeUtc__CommandLine `7236__2024-06-20t09:10:51.2193152z__vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all`. Further investigation identified that system recovery setting tampering was observed on the same host, where adversaries might be attempting to delete or remove built-in operating systems data and turn off recovery services to prevent recovering a corrupted system. This may deny access to available backups and recovery options.
question.question: During the system recovery setting tampering, what process and command line was used to disable automatic Windows recovery features?
question.answer: Process Id: 4828, Command Line: `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no`
solution: An attack was detected where file backups were deleted via `vssblatemp.exe`.

System recovery settings were tampered with using the process `bcdedit.exe` which was launched with the command line `bcdedit /set recoveryenabled no` at `2024-06-20t09:31:59.6743318z` with Process ID `4828`.

question.context: A suspicious and anomalous behavior was observed involving a user on device `vnevado-win11t`. This behavior suggested a potential compromise and a series of unusual activities might indicate that this device is involved in a possible human-operated attack by an advanced threat actor. During this investigation, an alert indicating activity from a Russia-based cybercriminal group, Manatee Tempest, was raised. Manatee Tempest is known for their partnership with Mustard Tempest, and they use techniques like drive-by download, malvertising, and FakeUpdates to gain initial access. They proceed with BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike for lateral movement and ransomware deployment, often using domain fronting for command-and-control.
question.question: What is the URL associated with the activity from Manatee Tempest?
solution: The user account `dp5hn` has exhibited suspicious and anomalous behavior on their device.
The URL `vectorsandarrows.com` is associated with the cybercriminal group Manatee Tempest, which uses drive-by downloads and other methods to gain access to target networks.

It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

('The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

('The actor that Microsoft tracks as Manatee Tempest is a Russia-based cybercriminal group that has been active since June 2014. It was notorious for one of its earliest malware lexpaigns – the Dridex banking trojan. Manatee Tempest is also one of the first groups to be sanctioned by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) in 2019.

Manatee Tempest’s tactics rely on a partnership with Mustard Tempest, an access broker that facilitates access to target networks. Manatee Tempest has been observed targeting organizations across a diverse array of industries with methods such as drive-by download, including malvertising and FakeUpdates (also known as SocGholish) infections facilitated by Mustard Tempest to obtain initial access, followed by BLISTER loader to deliver Cobalt Strike beacons which are used for lateral movement and ransomware deployment. The actor also uses domain fronting to establish command-and-control channel for Cobalt Strike beacons. Manatee Tempest overlaps with activity tracked by the cyber intelligence industry as EvilCorp, UNC2165, and Indrik Spider.

question.question: Related to this alert, there was also an incident where file backups were deleted. Can you identify the command used in the process that deleted the file snapshots and shadow copies?
solution: A possible attempt to access Primary Refresh Token (PRT) was detected for the AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
File backups, including all snapshots and shadow copies, were deleted using process `7236` at `2024-06-20t09:10:51.2193152z` with the command line `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all`.

question.context: A security incident was triggered due to a known credential theft tool execution command line. The process mimikatz.exe was used, showing an intent to dump user credentials. In relation to this, there was suspicious access to the LSASS service involving a specific file.
question.question: What is the name of the file involved in the suspicious access to the LSASS service?
solution: A known credential theft tool named `mimikatz.exe` was executed.
Suspicious access to the LSASS service, potentially attempting to decrypt user passwords using the file `cryptdll.dll`, was detected.

question.context: Start Alert: File backups were deleted, performed by `vssblatemp.exe` with Process ID 1900 and command line `vssblatemp.exe delete shadows /all`. The incident also involves a blocked Command and Control behavior alert. The blocked action is related to active malware, which can receive remote commands to conduct cyber attacks.
question.question: What is the URL involved in the Command and Control behavior that was blocked?
solution: All file snapshots and shadow copies have been deleted via WMI or VSSAdmin by the user with AadUserId `731adb71-b11c-4bbf-850b-57989b350e96`.
Command and Control (C2) behavior was blocked from the URL `http://vectorsandarrows.com/`.
